headline: Children, patients can breathe easier
body: NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court order banning sale of firecrackers in Delhi-NCR has been welcomed by doctors. Bursting crackers, they say, makes some happy but there are others - particularly children and the elderly - who have to struggle to breathe during Diwali. Many of them are either asked to move out of the city to avoid the distress or get admitted in case of exacerbation of asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)."The SC verdict was expected and much awaited. /Celebrations shouldn't be at the cost of shortened life," said Dr Arvind Kumar, founder trustee, Lung Care Foundation. Firecrackers contain chemicals like sulphur, mercury and lead. When burnt, particulate matters (PM) and gases are released.Doctors say inhaling air laden with them chokes the lungs. "The chemicals inhaled get deposited in the lungs and affect the breathing process. For those with pre-existing lung health problem, it gets deadly and they have to be rushed to hospital for mechanical ventilation in rare circumstances," Dr Raj Kumar, the head of pulmonary medicine at V P Chest Institute.He said V P Chest Institute witnesses nearly 20% to 30% increase in OPD rush post-Diwali. "The incidence of pneumonia also goes up. This is because lungs damaged by exposure to high levels of pollution become vulnerable to bacterial infections," said another doctor. "We welcome the SC order. However, the pollution levels in north India are multiple times higher than the national standards throughout the winter months, hence we also need to look at a stricter, comprehensive and time bound action plan to address all sources of air pollution across India," a spokesperson of Greenpeace India said.Burn injuries due to fire-crackers are also common. Every year, more than 300 people with burn injuries are brought to the city hospitals on Diwali. Injuries to the hand or face are most common, say doctors. "People must practice self-restraint and understand why bursting fire-crackers needs to be stopped," a senior doctor at AIIMS said./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Doctors blame stubble burning as city sees 20% rise in respiratory diseases
body: GURUGRAM: A week after farmers began burning stubble in Punjab and Haryana, city-based hospitals are reporting 20% increase in respiratory diseases, including bronchitis, asthma, and cough and cold, compared to last month. Till Monday this month, city-based hospitals recorded around 100 cases of respiratory diseases, whereas the number stood at around 80 in September."There is an almost 20 % increase in footfall of patients with respiratory diseases in the out-patient department," said Dr Manoj K Goel, head, department of pulmonology, Fortis Memorial.According to doctors, changing weather conditions and stubble burning are the main causes for the increase. "Rising pollution levels are impacting us in more ways than we completely understand. /There is an increase of about 25% in the number of patients with respiratory diseases related to air pollution. Change in weather and stubble burning are major factors behind rise in pollution," said Dr Himanshu Garg, head, department of respiratory diseases, Artemis Hospital. "Of all other factors, open field burning is responsible for 12-25% of particulate pollution. Fall in wind speed is also making the situation worse. We're witnessing almost 40-50% increase in OPD patients with respiratory problems," said Dr S P Byotra, head, internal medicine, Sir Ganga Ram Hospital, Delhi. Doctors also said there's a rise in the number of younger patients. "Earlier, respiratory problems were common in the age group of 50-60, but with change in pollutants, these diseases are now common in the age group of 25-60. The number of COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) has risen," said Dr Arunesh Kumar, senior consultant, pulmonology, Paras Hospitals. Experts fear rise in stubble burning, along with fall in temperature and wind speed, will trigger severe air pollution in the city this year. "We're expecting a 40% rise in number of patients with respiratory diseases from last year. Pollution masks and indoor air quality control may provide relief," said a doctor at Civil Hospital./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Maharashtra cabinet approves climate change action plan
body: MUMBAI: The tribal district of Nandurbar is the most vulnerable in the state to climate change. In fact the most vulnerable region to climate change are the districts in North Maharashtra of which Nandurbar is a part. The other districts include Dhule, Jalgaon and Nashik.Since 1880 the temperature has increased by 0.8 degrees celsius and there is more presence of greenhouse gases such as methane, carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, according to a report prepared by The Energy and Resources Institute (TERI), Delhi for the Maharashtra government.Nearly a decade after the union ministry of environment and forests mandated that every state prepare a climate change action plan, the government has finally approved the recommendations of TERI.The state government has accepted 14 recommendations. /It will set up a panel of experts to oversee the implementation of the policy. One of the main recommendations it has accepted is to protect the area around the origins of a river. Ensure plantation of trees to prevent soil erosion to reduce the intensity of floods. Through jan sabhas the government will spread awareness about the need for protection of the environment and through people participation it will create climate proof villages.Climate change will vastly affect the yield of sugarcane, cotton and wheat, and these will be prone to diseases unless newer technologies that increase resilience against climate change are adopted. The policy approved by the cabinet states it will invest in research on seeds and fruits and promote native varieties.The policy states it will frame a policy disallowing construction in the floodplains of rivers. It will conserve wetlands, mangroves and coral reefs. Recently the Centre approved new rules for Wetlands wherein it has excluded manmade water reservoirs from the definition of wetlands. Even saltpans have been excluded.It will set strict norms to reduce air pollution from vehicles. The state government has assured the Centre that it will introduce congestion tax in urban areas to discourage use of private vehicle where it has created sufficient public transport capacity./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Burst crackers with less decibel: Tirupur admin
body: Tirupur: Ahead of Diwali festival, the district administration has advised people not to burst crackers which create sound more than 125 decibel (at a distance of four meters).If the residents choose the crackers which create more light rather than sound, it will be fine for the environment, it added. In a press release, collector K S Palanisamy said since the researchers say that the air pollution caused by the fire crackers could lead to respiratory diseases, it is important to burst lesser quantity of crackers. If possible, do not prefer the crackers at all, he added.As per the Supreme Court ruling, the crackers should not be burst between 10pm and 6am. Moreover, it should not also be burst in crowded places or the places like hospitals, schools and courts, said the release.It is not safe to allow the children to fire the crackers alone and the parents should ensure that the former follow all the precaution and safety measures. Rocket-type fire crackers should not be used, it may create fire accidents, added the release./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Doctors give thumbs up to 'right to breathe'
body: NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court's decision to ban sale of firecrackers in Delhi and NCR has received a thumbs up from medical experts. On Wednesday, few of them got together to urge people to celebrate a smoke-free and green Diwali, as part of the #MyRightToBreathe campaign.Leading doctors urged the public to revive traditional practices such as planting saplings, lighting earthen lamps and wax candles, creating rangolis with eco-friendly colours as a first step towards combating the dangerous levels of air pollution in Delhi.Popular public figures like Virat kohli, Kapil Dev, Rohit Sharma, Virender Sehwag, Nina Gupta and Arjun Nagpal have also voiced their support towards saying no to crackers by sharing videos and pledges on their social media accounts to urge people to spread awareness. "We owe it to our children to give them clean air to breathe," said Dr Anupam Sibal, senior paediatrician and group medical director at Apollo hospitals groups. /He added that children have smaller airways compared to adults and suffer more when the air is polluted."Wheezing, difficulty in breathing and aggravation of respiratory allergies are some of the manifestations we see," Dr Sibal said.Radiologist Dr Harsh Mahajan said long-term effects are unseen and more dangerous. "Everyone living in Delhi is smoker, regardless of whether he or she smokes or not. We breathe in dirty air which affects lung function and is a cause of many serious illnesses," he said. Dr Mahajan stressed on self-realisation and people's movement against bad air for a better future. Last year, doctors said, schools had to be closed because the air had become so dangerous to breathe.Dr Arvind Kumar, chief thoracic surgeon at Sir Ganga Ram hospital advocated for this cause by reiterating the severe health-related consequences of cracker-bursting. Gopal Shankaranarayanan, advocate and one of the panelists, spoke about the comprehensive 12 point petition filed in the apex court, the need for better fuel norms among other issues and advocating with the government for introducing electric buses as a cleaner mode of transport for the city. Every year, Diwali celebrations make the air in and around Delhi and surrounding areas thick with smog and suspended particulate matter leading to residents and children feeling breathless and vulnerable to asthmatic attacks./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Waste burning chokes Sec 65, MCG, Huda debate jurisdiction
body: Gurgaon: Residents of Sector 65 have complained of rampant dumping and burning of waste on vacant plots in a blatant violation of NGT directives, causing air pollution in the area. However, Huda and MCG, instead of taking steps to check the menace, are apparently busy in a debate over jurisdiction.Residents claimed waste, collected from Sector 65 and its nearby areas, was disposed of and burnt on empty plots located behind underconstruction Grand Hyatt and Ireo-IT SEZ."Toxic fumes caused by rampant burning of medical waste, plastics and other harmful substances pose a serious threat to the residents living at nearby condominiums, like Grand Arch, Tata Raisana," said Tarun Puri, a local resident. They alleged that the problem had been persistent for over four months now and that they had approached the authorities multiple times, but in vain. /"A few days ago, MCG officials visited the spot. Incidentally, the society was engulfed in thick smoke that day. The officials only issued warnings, but nothing changed. Waste burning generally starts in the evening and goes on till night," said Saurabh Nangrekar, who lives at Ireo Grand Arch."We have raised the issue on the Swachh Bharat app. There are hundreds of kids living at these condominiums who are the worst sufferers," said Siddharth Sahni, another resident. Sources said, following repeated complaints, MCG had conducted raids in 2016 too and issued notices to several people, including the owners of the plots used for waste burning. It had stopped the waste burning for a brief period, but it began again.When approached, a senior MCG official said that they were aware of the problem and that they had taken action to address it. "We did an inspection and have asked people in the surrounding areas to not burn garbage in open areas," he said. Huda officials said it was a private developer's area and their responsibility was limited. However, sources said sanitation had been a major problem in all new sectors across Gurgaon. While Huda claims that the maintaining sanitation is MCG's responsibility, the corporation says it is yet to take charge in the new sectors./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: After SC order, PIL in Orissa HC seeks ban on crackers' sale
body: CUTTACK: Two days after a Supreme Court directive prohibiting the sale of firecrackers in the Delhi-National Capital Region (NCR) during Diwali, a public interest litigation with a similar prayer was filed in Orissa high court on Wednesday.The PIL has been filed by a social organization Bharatiya Bikash Parishad (BBP) and seeks the high court's intervention in the matter. The petitioner has argued that the festival of Diwali used to celebrated with the lighting of diyas to mark the victory of good over evil. It used to be confined to illuminating houses with diyas, but with changing times people started bursting harmful crackers and explosives for their pleasure.The petitioner has alleged that a wide variety of harmful crackers are being manufactured and sold in the market to lure buyers. /Bursting of crackers causes both noise and air pollution. This not only affects the environment, but may also cause illnesses among children and senior citizens."Diwali has turned into a nightmare for heart and asthma patients as their condition gets aggravated due to the loud noise of crackers and the smoke that emanates from it," alleged Surendra Panigrahi, who has filed the PIL on behalf of BBP.The petitioner has further contended that harmful crackers lead to several fire mishaps with many innocent people losing their lives due to it. To save mankind from annihilation, there is an urgent need to impose a ban on the sale and use of crackers during Diwali, prayed the petitioner.Citing the recent Supreme Court order as an eye-opener, he said conscious measures should be taken to follow the order in Odisha as well.The matter is likely to be taken up for hearing on Friday, said Panigrahi./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Villagers raise a stink at Naregaon
body: Aurangabad: Those living in proximity to the Naregaon dump yard have now taken it upon themselves to protest against the civic body, demanding removal and relocation of the garbage depot elsewhere. According to the villagers, while they have been struggling against the depot for the last 35 years from 7pm onwards they would not allow vehicles belonging to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) to use the dumping ground. They stated that the dumping yard has taken a toll on their health for years and now they have decided to oppose it tooth and nail. /Officials fear that this might lead to piling of garbage across the city.The villagers, who have formed the Kachra Depot Hatao Andolan Kruti Samiti, said on Thursday that they have decided restrict all garbage-carrying vehicles that belong to the AMC from entering the premises of the Naregaon dumping yard. The garbage depot falls under the purview of Mandki-Gopalpur Gram Panchayat.Manoj Gayake and Ravi Gayake, who represented the protesters before the media, said that the village gram panchayat has already passed a resolution to this effect and forwarded it to the civic body as well as the concerned authorities a long time ago. "We had also alerted the administration that villagers would not allow vehicles to enter the premises from October 13," they stated.The dumping yard is spread across 44 acres land owned by the government.The representatives of the villagers pointed out that the civic administration had made two futile attempts to process garbage but no concrete measure was taken. "Thousands of tonnes of garbage is being dumped at this site causing air pollution and a nasty smell in at least 13 villages, including Mandki, Antapur, Gopalpur, Daulatpur and Palshi apart from causing tremendous inconvenience to the residents of five city wards including Naregaon, Chikalthana and Brijwadi. The water in the wells too has got contaminated while causing different sorts of diseases," they said.They added that as many as 12 gram panchayats affected by the dumping yard have resolved not to allow AMC to dump waste in their vicinity./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: 500 villagers camp at waste depot entrance, stop trucks from entering
body: Aurangabad: The residents of 12 villages situated around Naregaon waste depot began an indefinite protest against garbage dumping at the site on Friday. Trucks laden with trash were parked at the AMC ground near Central Naka after residents stopped the vehicles from entering the waste depot.About 500 protesters, comprising men, women and children, are camping at the entrance of the landfill. The residents of the twelve villages - Mandki, Gopalpur, Mahal Pimpri, Naregaon, Pisadevi, Pokhri, Kachhe Ghati, Varud Kaji, Palsi, Rampur, Sultanpur and Hirapur - issued a warning on Friday that they would not allow further dumping of garbage at the site and would communicate with only the mayor, or the municipal commissioner or district collectorate authorities. /Till late on Friday, AMC commissioner D M Mugalikar could not be reached for comment on the issue and there was no breakthrough in the logjam.The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation had began dumping waste from the city at the 44-acre landfill in 1984. In 2004, the Bombay high court told the municipal corporation to stop dumping garbage at the site, which had been used to its full capacity by 2003. Fifteen years later, however, the civic body has still not been able to make any alternate arrangement or put in place a waste processing mechanism to reduce the garbage.On Friday, TOI had reported how the dumping yard had taken a toll on the lives of the villagers. Representatives of the village had said the untreated garbage has led to the contamination of groundwater in the nearby areas and also caused air pollution. Villagers said the garbage burns throughout the day, but in the evening, the smoke emanating from the mountain of trash causes breathing problems among many people. Farmers also say their vegetable crops have been affected due to the land being contaminated by the filth and trash.Meanwhile, Gauri Mirashi, solid waste management expert and Civic Response Team (CRT) founder, said that finding a new waste dumping site is not a solution. "A similar situation is being witnessed at landfill sites across the country. Decentralized dry waste processing and composting are the only answer to this problem," she said./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Green fight: Centre ties itself in knots
body: New Delhi: A report submitted in the Supreme Court last week by Harish Salve, the amicus curiae in air pollution matters, highlighted how the Union environment ministry's stand on various measures to control pollution contradicts the Centre's research reports and findings.For example, the ministry had submitted before the apex court that there is no need to set targets to follow air pollution norms. But the Central Pollution Control Board's (CPCB) notification dated April 11, 1994, said that the national air quality standards should be met on at least 98% of the days. The planning commission's 12th five-year plan said states should meet the national ambient air quality standards by 2017. In a comprehensive action plan submitted to the Supreme Court to control air pollution, SC-mandated Environment Pollution Control Authority (EPCA) had suggested that a reduction of 69.7% in PM2.5 concentrations and 74% in PM10 concentrations is needed to meet the annual average safe standard in the capital. But the environment ministry had submitted that there is no need to set a target.It had also said that a comprehensive action plan is not needed because a graded response action plan is already in place and a 42-point action plan was devised by the ministry earlier. /Amicus' note said that "graded response action plan has been notified under sub-section (1) of Section 3 of the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986 (29 of 1986). This makes the plan legally binding. Similarly, comprehensive action plan will have to be notified. It may be noted that the comprehensive action plan has been prepared by EPCA in response to the order of the court dated February 6, 2017. EPCA integrated the relevant plans of the Union and state governments, and the recent orders of the court. It also consulted the governments of Delhi, Haryana, Rajasthan and UP. The plan was drafted in consultation with CPCB and it didn't object to the targets set or action points suggested.The environment ministry also stated that there is no conclusive evidence to establish direct correlation of death exclusively with air pollution and that international studies should not be cited as reference to the impact of air pollution in India. The amicus pointed out, " This is similar to the fact that no doctor certifies death by tobacco smoking but it is clear that tobacco is a causative factor in cancer".He referred to a report by the Union health ministry released in 2015-Report of the Steering Committee on Air Pollution and Health Related Issues. It cited evidence linking air pollution exposure to adverse health effects and made policy recommendations. The environment ministry's report, State of Environment 2015, stated there are several studies across the world and also in India that prove air pollution caused or aggravated acute and chronic diseases.The ministry claimed CNG is one of the major contributors of oxides of nitrogen (NOX) and is expected to increase PM1 (ultrafine pollution particles) in the air. But in reply to a question in Lok Sabha in 2016, International Agency for Research in Cancer classified outdoor air pollution (particulate matter) as carcinogenic to humans. The environment ministry also said BRT is not needed to curb pollution in NCR, but the amicus highlighted that the urban development ministry's Delhi Decongestion Plan recommends BRT, along with metro and higher parking charges. The ministry is also against shutting the Badarpur power plant that had been recommended by EPCA in the comprehensive action plan./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Respiratory problems increase, may worsen after Diwali
body: GURUGRAM: Even before the arrival of winter and Diwali, the city is witnessing a sharp spike in the number of patients suffering from respiratory problems. The increase has been reported in both government and private hospitals in the city. And doctors blame increasing air pollution for this increase and expect the situation to worsen after Diwali.In the past week, Civil Hospital has reported a daily footfall of 40 to 45 patients suffering from respiratory diseases, including bronchitis, asthma, cough and breathlessness.Dr Pradeep Sharma, acting principal medical officer of the hospital, said earlier the figure used to be just one to two a day. /"Earlier, the patients used to either children or those above 50 years. Now, most of these patients are in the age group of 25 to 60 years," he told TOI on Saturday."Vehicular emission is one of the main reasons for the rise in air pollution levels. Also, indoor pollution is becoming a major cause of respiratory diseases in Gurgaon residents," he added.Private hospitals are also reporting a substantial increase in footfall of patients with respiratory diseases. Paras Hospitals, for instance, has reported 315 cases of respiratory problems in the past one month. Dr Arunesh Kumar, senior consultant (pulmonology), at the hospital, said, "Cough, both dry and one with white sputum, is a common symptom we are looking at these days. In early stages of a lung disease, shortness of breath occurs only with exertion and if the lung condition progresses. The breathlessness may occur with minimum physical activity or even while resting."Doctors are expecting the situation to worsen after Diwali."Despite a ban on the sale of firecrackers, we are expecting a 25% rise in respiratory diseases due to high pollution levels and toxic gases from the cracker fumes. The exceeding safety limits of toxic particles in the air will also lead to rise in cases of pneumonia, allergies, cardiovascular arrest etc," said Dr Manoj Goel, director and head of pulmonology department, Fortis Memorial and Research Institute./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Delhi may breathe easier this Diwali
body: The city is likely to witness cleaner air this Diwali and a less polluted year overall, Union environment ministry and Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) officials have said, based on forecasts of meteorological conditions and anti-pollution steps which are beginning to show results.The Supreme Court's recent ban on sale of firecrackers is also expected to help prevent deterioration of air beyond last year's level.Weather conditions such as clear skies and inflow of dry winds expected over the next week -Diwali is on Thursday -support what Arun Kumar Mehta, the senior most official in the ministry overseeing the gamut of pollution control measures, said."This year will certainly be better than 2016. We won't see a repeat of last year's post-Diwali emergency conditions that prompt authorities to resort to measures such as oddeven (car rationing)," he said. Though the city has seen a sharp spike in air pollution since last Monday , experts said better days, extending beyond Diwali, could lie ahead with a shift in wind direction. "There has been a haze over the region due to easterly winds bringing in moisture. /This caused the rise in pollution. The wind direction has now changed to northnorthwesterly , which is drier and will help clear the haze.These conditions are expected to continue till after Diwali," said Dipankar Saha, head of the CPCB air lab.Clear skies, expected next week, are likely to create conditions for vertical and horizontal movement of air, which helps clear pollution, Saha said, explaining why a current rise in pollution will ebb.Last year, weather conditions had not only prevented Diwali pollution from dissipating but had also transported smoke from crop fires to NCR in the days after the festival, resulting in a severe fall in air quality . This year has seen more moderate days and fewer very poor days. Though the Supreme Court order on fire crackers will help, Mehta, additional secretary in the environment ministry , said the roundthe-year action and monitoring of pollution by the ministry and all NCR states have also begun to bear fruit. The measures include action and incentives to control stubble burning.This practice continues but some headway has been claimed in reducing the farm fires as compared to last year.All the NCR states are acting for stricter enforcement of pollution under control certifi cate for vehicles. The entry and exit of heavy vehicles is also being restricted. Other ministry officials said a full enforcement of the ban on firecracker sales is not expected.However, the action in tandem with awareness campaigns by the Centre, NGOs and citizens will help curb use of firecrackers to a large extent, they said.The ministry had last week reviewed the overall situation in a meeting chaired by the minister of state for environment and forests Mahesh Sharma. The minister discussed preventive measures such as curbs on cropstubble burning and strictly enforcing `pollution under control' (PUC) certificates.Asked about absence of any credible and reliable study on the impact of bursting of firecrackers on the environment, a CPCB official said neither the pollution control board nor the environment ministry has the mandate to conduct such a study . He said the ministry can only notify the standard which has to be prepared by another government agency -Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organisation -under the ministry of commerce and industry./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Smokescreen over Patiala highway, VIP Road choking
body: Zirakpur: The ban on burning crop residue has gone up in smoke around the VIP Road housing societies. The smokescreen over the Patiala highway cutting through these flaming fields blinds the drivers.Abhishek Sharma of Nirmal Chhaya apartments on the VIP Road reports signs of "asthma, bronchitis, and other respiratory diseases" in the housing society. Confronted, the agriculture department officials who have failed to enforce the ban said: "Farmers are aware that burning stubble can lower the fertility of their land. /But they resort to the practice due to the unavailability of heavy vehicles and proper farming equipment."The agriculture department sees Derabassi as one of the worst affected areas. It has 22,000 hectares under cultivation-12,000 under paddy, while the rest under Basmati and vegetables. Mohali's 31,000 hectares of farmland includes 25,000 for paddy and 6,000 for Basmati. "Even though it has added to air pollution, stubble burning has declined a lot from previous years. The government is making efforts to reduce it further," an agriculture department official said.Officials of the pollution-control board said the installation of an ethanol plant and 10-to-12 biomass units will solve the problem of stubble burning in a few years. RTI (Right To Information) activist Navjit Singh Miglani, who lives on the VIP Road, said: "The government seems insensitive to the problem of stubble burning near residential areas. Ashes of the burnt crop residue fly into housing societies and cause breathing problems."Sugandha Bali of Savitry Society on the VIP Road said: "Almost every second child and family elder in the society is down with breathing problems. The government needs to be sensitive to the public's difficulties."/For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Majority of Delhiites welcome ban on firecrackers, suggest effective implementation
body: MANGALURU: While the Supreme Court ban on sale of firecrackers in Delhi-NCR has been drawing mixed reactions from people in general, majority of working professionals in the region have supported such prohibition, noted a quick random survey by ASSOCHAM Social Development Foundation.While there is no doubt about construction activities, road dust, vehicular pollution, waste burning and other such factors being majorly responsible for deteriorating air quality in and around the city, majority of right-minded people in Delhi-NCR feel that no source of pollution is too small to be ignored when it comes to the public health concerns, highlighted the survey conducted by ASSOCHAM as part of its Corporate Social Development initiative.The ASSOCHAM Social Development Foundation (ASDF) randomly interacted with about 2,000 people in general at entry and exit points of Delhi Metro stations across the city during the last weekend to ascertain views of common Delhiites on Supreme Court's October 9 order suspending sale of firecrackers in Delhi-NCR."Banning sale of firecrackers is a very welcome move as smoke from fireworks is a common trigger for many individuals with asthma, many people experience respiratory distress, bronchitis, persistent cough, burning eyes, itchy throat and other related problems," said ASSOCHAM president, Sandeep Jajodia while releasing the findings of the survey."Air pollution in Delhi-NCR is not just devastating the environment but it might also hurt brand India thereby severely hitting sectors like tourism, outdoor recreation as people tend to stay away from polluted areas to avoid dense and toxic air," said Jajodia."Sunshine and good air have become luxury for Delhiities who have been dealing with anxieties over pollution, traffic, and related stress," added the ASSOCHAM chief."Though schools along with resident welfare associations and those in healthcare/medical sector/community have been carrying out campaigns across India with a view to sensitise people about harmful effects of firecrackers which has also led to growing environmental awareness, a judicious mix of command and control measures is the key to protect public health as pollution levels have only been going up during Diwali from year-to-year," he said further./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Airtight solution to traffic cops' woes
body: New Delhi: Delhi Traffic Police has issued 10,000 hi-tech pollution masks to its personnel to help them deal with smoke-induced breathing problems. The masks were issued with the help of a private company to brace for pollution ahead of winter.In 2015, around 200 personnel who manned major traffic intersections and rotaries in the city were given these masks. However, they were later withdrawn since the quality of the masks was not up to the mark."The idea is to protect the 3,500 men on the roads from fumes and dust during this season. /During our health check-up camps, most men complained about pollution-induced illnesses that can be curtailed with these specially-designed masks," said special commissioner (traffic) Dependra Pathak.The N-95 mask is especially designed to absorb fumes, carbon and dust that often lead to breathing problems. It comes with a replaceable filter that can be changed after a defined period.With the government planning to introduce the graded response plan ahead of Diwali, cops feel that the masks would be of immense help. Prolonged exposure to air pollution can lead to chronic respiratory diseases, lung cancer and acute respiratory infections.Unlike the old masks, the new ones are adjustable and can be tightened. The earlier ones were not airtight due to which their primary purpose was lost. "Earlier, we got complaints about the masks being inconvenient and hot. The news masks allow ventilation due to which the men will feel comfortable," said a senior police officer.Studies by different agencies across the country show that respiratory problems, heart diseases, cancer, musculoskeletal and neurological disorders are quite prevalent among traffic police personnel. In fact, a study conducted by Maulana Azad medical college a few years ago showed that most of them suffered from severe asthmatic problems./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: No smog likely during Diwali in city
body: Jaipur: The favourable climatic conditions in Jaipur has minimised the chances of smog over the skies creating health hazards especially for the kids, elders and those suffering from breathing problems.The weather forecast for the next two days, Thursday and Friday, which witnesses 80% of the firecrackers has a clear sky. The maximum temperature to remain 34 degrees Celsius and minimum to touch 22 degrees Celsius which is ideal for the particles emitted out of smoke to settle down in the atmosphere."The worst situation comes during low temperatures or a foggy weather. /The fog when reacts with smog forms an envelope over the sky making it a chamber. It makes an ideal condition for the air pollution to reach alarming levels. This year, the Diwali is falling in October which is known for moderate temperature giving a respite to the citizens," said Bhuvnesh Mathur, an officer at Rajasthan Pollution Control Board.The board has made elaborate arrangements to monitor the air and noise pollution along with real-time pollution data on Raj Vayu application. "Our air and noise pollution metres at eight places give a picture of the state. Through Raj Vayu application anyone downloads and use it for making visits," said Mathur who ruled out that Jaipur is even near to alarming levels of air pollution. The board will upload the data on noise and air pollution levels during Diwali on its website."The whole idea is to make an assessment and interpretation of the data by engaging general public via media to create awareness on the subject," said Mathur./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

headline: Clouds of 'poor' air quality hover over Diwali skyline
body: Pune: The city's air quality is likely to be moderate on the day of Diwali but will reach the "poor" levels on Octover 20 and 21, an Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology's (IITM) SAFAR forecast for this year's festival of lights stated on Wednesday. The System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) forecast stated that Mumbai's air quality may be better than Pune because of the favourable weather conditions in the metro city. The forecast, meanwhile, said pollution levels in both Mumbai and Pune were likely to be less than the Diwali of 2016.During the period between October 19 and 23, Pune may see two days - October 20 and 21- with a poor air quality index. /On the other hand, Mumbaikars may have to face just one day, October 20, when the air quality index will be "poor".AQI level from 0-50 is considered good, 51-100 is satisfactory, 101-200 is moderate, 201-300 is poor, 301-400 is very poor, and 401 and above is severe.Though the air quality in Mumbai might worsen on October 20, it will still be slightly better than what has been the forecast for Pune on the day. The health impact of a "poor" air quality index leads to increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms in sensitive individuals, with children and elderly at risk. Everyone may begin to experience some level of discomfort when the index touches this level and it is advised that people with heart or lung diseases, older adults and children should avoid outdoor activities during such a time.Gufran Beig, project director, SAFAR, IITM, told TOI that the air quality in Mumbai will be better than last year because of the rain there on October 15 and 16. "The monsoon sea breeze in Mumbai, which blows from sea to land, will naturally help in sweeping away the Diwali pollutants. Pune, on the other hand, has been relatively dry in comparison to Mumbai, especially since the last three or four days. Also, it does not have the benefit of sea breeze like Mumbai," Beig said.As a combination of several weather parameters plays a big role in controlling the air pollution in a region, the SAFAR forecast for Pune also stated that the air quality in the city during the Diwali period "is expected to be much better than what it was in 2016 because of the rain in October". Another factor is monsoon is yet to withdraw from here.In case of Mumbai, the forecast stated, that the air quality this Diwali may be the best ever since SAFAR became operational in the metro in 2015. This will be because of the widespread rain in and around Mumbai during the current period. "On October 18, the winds in Mumbai were north-westerly. During Diwali, the winds will become northerly and the city will witness partly cloudy skies and moderate wind speed. This will not allow the pollutants to get stagnant in Mumbai," the forecast said./For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com
